column2: Australia;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings);I hate XXXX. But the off the wood
column3: when done correctly is something I am happy to drink. Donï¿½t go looking for wood flavour
column4: that isnï¿½t the what this is about. It is simply old school brewing storage and serving pale lager. Therefore it is less carbonated (so head doesnï¿½t last
column5: but a great mouth feel)
column6: unpasteurised (so a darker brown than the usual forex pale) and has a fuller flavour - particularly because it is not served ice cold. Otherwise it has a XXXX flavour
column7: without the metallic / skunked flavour I often associate with most macro beers. It is the way you always hope XXXX will taste
column10: so donï¿½t go expecting an abby brew. Other plus is that they donï¿½t charge a premium for it.

column2: Australia;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings);Fruity sweet nose. Little carbonation. Slightly sweet taste
column3: dry bitter finish. A little biscuit. Being gravity fed means youï¿½re not hammered into submission by bubbles. An interesting aside
column4: nothing more. Try it if you are in Brisbane.

column2: Australia;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings);Cask at Breakfast Creek Hotel
column3: Brisbane. Not much difference to the draught version. Perhaps slightly darker and somewhat fresher than the regular being unpasteurised. No wood aroma or flavour.

column2: Australia;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings);Lagers are not much in the looks or aroma department
column3: but I was very favourably impressed by a couple of pints off the wood at the Brekky Creek Hotel last week! Excellent palate and great flavour - quite a change after a week of XXXX Gold out of bottles and the tap.

column2: Australia;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings);Itï¿½s not aged in the wood
column3: itï¿½s just packaged in a wooden cask rather than a metal one and sent out to the pub. However there are several advantages over the regular keg version. Itï¿½s not pasteurised at the brewery so has a slightly fresher flavour
column4: and is served under gravity rather than being forced out by carbon dioxide. So whilst it isnï¿½t a ï¿½real aleï¿½ in the British sense
column5: it is slightly cleaner and less fizzy than the normal pub version. I like it and often stop in for one at the Brekkie Creek.

column2: Australia;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings);I have to disagree with the past raters on this one.... Aroma was far cleaner and less fruity than the standard XXXX
column3: good clarity and a nice tight head which lasted quite well. Flavour was without that common sugar flavour so prevalent in mainstream XXXX. maybe the brew I tried (at the Breakfast Creek) had spent some more tme on the wood... but it was a nice enough brew.

column2: Australia;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings);Couldn't taste the wood

column4: so it gets the same rating as the other one.

column4: very carbonated cola color. Served with an approximately 2 finger beige head. Head fades to a thick collar and very little lacing is left. S- The nose is subtle-but in line for the style. Banana is the main character but sourdough bread has almost equal strength as the backbone. T- The initial flavor is heavy on banana with a substantial bready yeast background. The finish is consistent with the initial flavor but the sourdough bread impression grows a little bit. Nothing lingers on the palate. P- Medium carbonation and light to medium weight body. Fairly smooth. O- This is a decent dunkel...but nothing special. It fits the bill pretty well for the style. Itï¿½s pretty heavy on banana and could use a little bit of spice. Definitely worth a try. column4: Paisley in June 1998. Cask
column5: handpump dispense. Clear pale garnet in colour with a thin white head. Slight hint of berry fruit in the short malty aroma. Thin mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt gives digestive biscuit in the robust malt base with a fruity tang of blackcurrant also present. Bitter hop resins impart a dry bitter aftertaste which compliments the woody malt well. Finish is dry but bitter sweet with woody notes ever present. A robust ESB style ale which is full of flavour and an ideal session ale.

column3: United States;Blonde Ale / Golden Ale;Andrew's Brewing Company;Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a nice looking golden yellow color with streams of carbonation seen rising to fill a one finger white foamy head that dissipated within about a minute. The lacing was light and sliding into the beer. The smell had a constrained sweet corn to sweet citrusy coated piney hops. As it warmed
column4: a decent caramel sweetness came out. The taste was mildly sweet as a fairly nice balanced piney bitterness came out. On the palate
column5: this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was there - nice and safe as it rolled over my tongue in a slight spritzy sort of way. Overall
column6: I almost want to say: was this an effort towards a hybrid of a blonde with an IPA? I liked it and would have it again.

column3: United States;Blonde Ale / Golden Ale;Andrew's Brewing Company;My Bottom Line: Generous honeyed cereals pleasantly lift leafy hops in this chewy and well-balanced Golden Ale. column5: I imagine. Bottle.

There is a good malt present but the hops are surprisingly strong. Good cherry and fruits. The flavor is excellent. There is a nice hoppiness and a strong fruit character. There is a light booze and and strong malt and caramel. The mouth feel is a little thin but well carbonated. There is a slick finish and it's quick fading. Good barley wine for sure ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column3: United States;Porter - Baltic;Old Dominion Brewing Company (AB InBev);Polish porter is really Baltic Porter
column4: a beer style that is a direct descendant of a British beer style
column5: known as Imperial Stout. In the 18th Century British brewers sent strong
column7: flavorful stouts to Russia and the Baltics as a winter warmer. These beers became so popular
column8: Russian/Baltic/Eastern European breweries(Poland being one of them
column9: hence the name) began brewing their own versions of this beer style with a slight twist. These breweries were lager breweries
column11: they used the lager yeast strains in their breweries
column12: instead of brewing with an ale yeast strain
column13: which was traditionally used in Imperial Stout. Baltic porter as a style was born
column15: it has be produced by only a handful of Russian/Baltic/Eastern European brewers. Poland has some excellent examples with brands like Okocim and Zyweic porters
column16: that have a strong cult following here in the US among Polish immigrants
column17: and beer lovers. Polish Porter is similar to Imperial Stout
column18: but due to the use of a lager yeast strain these beers tend to be smoother
column21: and lack the fruity estery flavors of an Imperial Stout. OD version is true to style
column22: but is a little low in alcohol
column23: coming in at only 5.8% abv. 8%-10%+ is on par with the style
column25: makes OD Winter Brew ï¿½03 a very
column27: with lots of big roasty/coffee aromas and flavors
column28: and lots of big chocolate malty aromas and flavors as well. It is brewed with German malts
column30: and of course a lager yeast strain. It is then cold conditioned like a lager
column33: just perfect for the Winter season. Old Dominion Winter Brew ï¿½03 pours to a beautiful
column34: deep brown to black color with a creamy white head
column35: and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose on this beer is fantastic with lots of big aromas of chocolate
column37: and roasty malt aroma with a nice back drop of herbal hop spice. The palate is firm with lots of big chocolate malt
column39: and roasty flavors that just glide over the tongue. The body on the beer is just so round and polished
column40: making it so drinkable. OD Winter Brew ï¿½03 finishes with more chocolate and coffee flavors up front
column41: then ends with some nice mild roasty flavors that lingers. Another fantastic beer from OD
column42: of a style of beer that is very rare. I would have liked a little more alcohol heat in this beer
column43: but the lower abv in this beer is only a minor flaw.

column4: 2003. A deep opaque black liquid poured from the bottle with about a half-inch of tan head residing on top. After making its entrance the head quickly dropped to a light scattering of bubbles leaving not much in the way of lace. Dark chocolate mixed with a bit of roasted malt mingled in the nose with notes of berries. There was also a bit of an earthy hop presence as well. The flavor started off a bit tart with berries before the coffee and dark chocolate stormed through. A roasted lingering aftertaste was how this finished. The body was about medium with a nice slick mouthfeel that went down very easy. Very drinkable as I would have had more if it was available. Hopefully this brew will return sometime
column5: but for now these bottles have held up pretty darn well.

column3: United States;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Red Brick Brewing Company;The beer came is an elegant brown bottle with a black strip pasted across the cap announcing this beer to be just under the 5.9% ABV cap. The beer poured out a hazy golden yellow color with fizzy short lived head. The carbonation level was very lively and appeared to not subside during the entire session of drinking. The lacing on the sides of the glass was also quite a bit better than most lagers. The smell was very faint with a note of husky soured grains and some noble hops. The malts displayed a refreshing lemony sourness and a distinctly smoky zing. It was also a bit metallic in character. The hops were generally subdued with not a lot of bitterness. The mouthfeel was quite good for the style. It was substantial and filling and did not feel watered down. This is a first beer for Inner City Brewing Company (which claims to be Atlantaï¿½s first African American owned brewery)
column4: and is contract brewed by Atlanta Brewing Company. I like this first effort
column5: and look forward to more offerings from them.
